Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student and Junior Researcher Travel Grant for 2017 Computational Geometry Week (CG Week 2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the 33rd International Symposium on Computational Geometry, July 4-7, 2017. SOCG is a focused conference that considers how to develop algorithms to solve problems best stated in geometric form. Research presented at previous SOCG conferences has had significant impact on the US economy in diverse areas that include algorithms for geometric data processing, computer vision, geographic information systems, manufacturing, graphics and visualization, optimization, computer-aided design, and networks.

This award aims to increase the impact of this conference on students, particularly those
from under-represented groups, by encouraging and enabling their participation, especially in cases
where travel expenses would otherwise preclude their attendance. Participation in a top-level event
such as SOCG can be educating, motivating, and useful for networking, both with other students
and with more senior scientists. This support dovetails nicely with the Young Researchers
Forum, a successful satellite event added to the conference in 2012 to encourage and promote
computational geometry research by students and postdocs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational geometry is the algorithmic study of problems involving geometric data. Research in the field addresses fundamental questions that arise from diverse application domains, including robotics, data science, networks, sensing, biology, computer vision, geometric modeling, manufacturing, and many other areas of science and engineering.

This project funded travel for students and junior researchers to participate in the events at the Computational Geometry Week in 2017 (in Brisbane, Australia), the Fall Workshop on Computational Geometry 2017 (in Stony Brook, NY), and the Computational Geometry Week in 2018 (in Budapest, Hungary). The CG Week events included the International Symposium on Computational Geometry (SoCG), which is the premiere forum for research in discrete and computational geometry, and their applications. The CG Week events also included the Young Researcher Forum, which allows a forum for students and recent graduates to disseminate their research findings. 

The main project outcome was the support for travel and participation for 39 young researchers, including 1 undergraduate student, 32 graduate students, and 6 postdoctoral young researchers, to three premiere computational geometry events in 2017-2018. These researchers actively participated in these events. Testimonials submitted after the events show that the young researchers were deeply engaged in the research events and benefited personally in their development of research skills and interactions with more senior researchers. As a broader impact of the project, new research collaborations were established, leading to new research and to training a new, diverse generation of scientists and engineers.
